question: Does caloric restriction lead to higher DNA methylation age (epigenetic age acceleration) compared with ad libitum feeding? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Twenty-two to 30-year-old rhesus monkeys exposed to 30% caloric restriction since 7-14 years of age showed attenuation of age-related methylation drift compared to ad libitum-fed controls such that their blood methylation age appeared 7 years younger than their chronologic age.
content.source_2: In 2.7â€“3.2-year-old mice subjected to 40% caloric restriction beginning at 0.3 years of age, DNA methylation clocks indicated accelerated epigenetic aging, with methylation age surpassing chronological age relative to ad libitum-fed controls.
content.source_3: Here, the authors provide evidence that age-related methylation drift correlates with lifespan and that caloric restriction in mice and rhesus monkeys results in attenuation of age-related methylation drift.
content.source_4: Although epigenetic information encoded by DNA methylation is typically tightly regulated, under caloric restriction the age-associated drift is amplified, leading to increased DNA methylation age compared with freely fed cohorts.
